user.biography: History isn't made by kings or politicians, it is made by us: billions of ordinary people ✊ podcast | social | patreon | store

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on September 07, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, outdoors and text that says 'BELDING Squatters in a block of London luxury flats appealing for help from out- side. Sympathizers tried to get food, water and bedding into the flats'.

node.text:
On this day, 8 September 1946, numerous empty properties were squatted by homeless ex-servicemen and their families in London in a wave of occupations across the country. 148 luxury flats in the Duchess of Bedford House in Kensington were squatted, as was a block in Weymouth Street, Marylebone, as well as houses in Campden Hill and Holland Park. In the coming days, more properties would be taken over around the city. Taken by surprise, police at the Duchess of Bedford House reportedly expressed sympathy for the families and arranged for a Women's Voluntary Service than to bring them hot drinks. But in subsequent occupations this did not recur and police took action like preventing supplies being brought to families and dispersing supporters with violence. Meanwhile, the Labour health minister, Aneurin Bevan, instructed local authorities to cut off gas and electricity to squatted premises. On September 20, a High Court injunction was issued against all of the London squats, and the occupiers then voluntarily left. Most of them went to a "rest centre" organised by local authorities, from which they were eventually rehoused.
*
We have mapped these, and other housing occupations, as well as hundreds of our other historical events. But we need your help in order to build a free website where people can browse them all. So if you can, please consider donating to our crowdfunder: https://www.gofundme.com/f/help-us-build-a-web-app
To access this hyperlink, click our link in bio, swipe left then click this photo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on September 07, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing, outdoors and text.

node.text:
New podcast! The final instalment of our four-part podcast miniseries about the May 18 uprising in Gwangju, South Korea, in 1980 against the US-backed military dictatorship of Chun Doo Hwan is out now. We speak with Kim Yong Ho, David Dollinger and Jeon Yong Ho, who took part in the events, as well as researcher and author Kap Su Seol. All four parts are currently available for early listening for our patreon supporters. Learn more, sign up and listen now at https://patreon.com/workingclasshistory
To access this hyperlink, click our link in bio, swipe left then click this photo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on September 07, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
On this day, 7 September 1942, Mildred Fish-Harnack, a writer and activist from the US who was active in the German resistance to Nazism, was arrested in Lithuania with her husband Arvid. 
They were leading activists in what the Nazis dubbed the "Red Orchestra", an underground anti-fascist circle. Fish-Harnack helped recruit many other activists to the circle, while her husband and she also helped funnel valuable German government secrets to Soviet intelligence. 
Fish-Harnack was initially sentenced to 6 years' hard labour, while her husband was sentenced to death. Hitler then ordered a retrial for Mildred, after which she was sentenced to death by guillotine. She was the only US civilian woman to be executed on Hitler's personal orders. 
Yesterday we interviewed her great great-niece, Rebecca Donner, who has written a detailed biography of Fish-Harnack which has just become a New York Times bestseller. We will be releasing it as a podcast episode later this year. So subscribe today to ensure you don't miss it by searching "Working Class History" on your favourite podcast app or visiting workingclasshistory.com/podcast

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on September 06, 2021. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
On this day, 7 September 1934, anti-fascists hung a banner atop the BBC headquarters advertising a demonstration against a rally by Oswald Mosley and his British Union of Fascists that weekend. While Mosley had been invited on the BBC to promote his Nazi views and advertise his demonstration, the BBC, like the rest of the British press, refused to give a platform to anti-fascists, or mention the counter-protest. Despite this, on the day, over 100,000 Londoners overwhelmed the fascists and their police guard and drove them out of Hyde Park.
Learn more about struggles against Mosley in the 1940s in our podcast episodes 35-37: https://workingclasshistory.com/2020/02/17/e35-37-the-43-group/

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on September 06, 2021. May be an image of 2 people.

node.text:
On this day, 6 September 1966, Mozambican-Greek revolutionary Dimitri Tsafendas assassinated the architect of apartheid, South African Prime Minister Hendrik Verwoerd, by stabbing him during a parliamentary session. Tsafendas (pictured) was at the time working in the Parliament building. 
Despite the bravery of his act, anti-apartheid leaders and his family distanced themselves from Tsafendas after the assassination. In his statement to police he was clear about his motives, saying that he "did believe that with the disappearance of the South African prime minister a change of policy would take place… I was so disgusted with the racial policy that I went through with my plan to kill the prime minister." 
But authorities decided to claim he was mentally ill so as to not admit their security had been beaten. And Tsafendas, under torture and facing the death penalty, eventually agreed to plead insanity.
Thus, he was subsequently found not guilty of murder by reason of insanity, and sent to a secure psychiatric hospital. He survived to see the end of the apartheid regime, but the new African National Congress government did not order his release. He died in custody in 1999. 
*
Read this and hundreds of other stories in our book, Working Class History: Everyday Acts of Resistance & Rebellion, available here: https://shop.workingclasshistory.com/products/working-class-history-everyday-acts-resistance-rebellion-book
To access this hyperlink, click our link in bio, swipe left then click this photo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on September 06, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and text.

node.text:
On this day, 6 September 1923, communist partisan hero Nada Dimić was born in the small village of Divoselo, in modern day Croatia. She was the only Croatian-Serb member of the country's first anti-fascist unit in Sisak. 
Dimić undertook raids and sabotage on railroads, and was arrested and tortured by the Ustaše (Croatian fascists). In prison she attempted suicide, but it was unsuccessful, however comrades then helped her escape, upon which she rejoined the struggle. 
Eventually Dimić was re-arrested by Italian troops who handed over to the Ustaše who again tortured her but again she refused to reveal any information, and she was executed some months later. 
*
If you value our work researching and promoting people's history like this, consider supporting us and getting access to exclusive content on patreon: https://patreon.com/workingclasshistory

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on September 05, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and people standing.

node.text:
On this day, 6 September 1925, anti-fascist resistance fighter Freddie Oversteegen (pictured, left) was born in Schoten, Netherlands. Together with her older sister Truus (right), she joined Dutch resistance at the age of 14. 
With her communist mother they initially helped shelter refugees and Jewish people, and later under German occupation joined a resistance cell in Haarlem alongside Hannie Schaft, sabotaging bridges and railway lines and assassinating Nazis and Dutch collaborators. 
Unlike Schaft, the Oversteegens survived the war and lived until their 90s.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on September 05, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of 2 people and people standing.

node.text:
On this day, 5 September 1939, Black civil rights activist and nurse Claudette Colvin was born in Montgomery, Alabama. When she was 15 she was arrested and convicted for refusing to give up her seat on a bus which she had been ordered to vacate for white passengers, several months before Rosa Parks (content note: sexual violence). However, civil rights leaders decided not to make a cause célèbre of her case after she became pregnant from a statutory rape, fearing negative publicity. Some local activists also believe that Colvin's dark skin was a factor in not choosing to take on her case.
Pictured: Colvin around the age of 15, and more recently.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on September 04, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
On this day, 5 September 1911, a UK-wide strike wave of schoolchildren was sparked when pupils in Llanelli, Wales walked out in sympathy with a boy who was disciplined by a deputy headmaster. From this one school, walkouts spread across the country to at least 62 towns and cities, with pupils demanding an end to corporal punishment, and for shorter hours. The schoolchildren's strikes followed a summer of workers' industrial disputes. 
This is a fantastic pamphlet about the walkouts: https://libcom.org/history/childrens-strikes-1911
Pictured: schoolchildren on strike in Shoreditch, London, 1911

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on September 04, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and outdoors.

node.text:
On this day, 4 September 2005, in the wake of hurricane Katrina the Danziger Bridge shootings took place, when several New Orleans police officers opened fire with assault weapons on an unarmed Black family. 
The Bartholomew family along with James Brissette, a 17-year-old friend, were on their way to a grocery store. Plainclothed police with machine guns then shot six of them, killing two and then stomping on one of the victims as he lay dying. Some of the victims were shot up to seven times and lost limbs. One man was shot five times in the back and a teenage girl was shot four times. Brissette and Ronald Madison were killed.
The police then fabricated a story claiming they had been fired on by four suspects, an officer had been shot and had to return fire. They even arrested one of the survivors and charged him with eight counts of attempting to kill police. The officer in charge of investigating the shootings helped fabricate evidence to support the shooters' lies. Guilty verdicts for the killers were handed down in 2011, six years after the crimes.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on September 03, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and standing.

node.text: On this day, 4 September 1895, Xiang Jingyu, communist and one of the pioneers of the Chinese women's movement, was born. She was an advocate for women's rights, as part of the liberation of the working class, and criticised sexist practices in the Communist Party. She led a strike of thousands of women silk factory workers in 1924. She was involved in organising women's support for the Canton-Hong Kong workers' strike the following year. Later she was betrayed and arrested in 1928 by French police. The French handed her over to the nationalist Kuomintang movement, who then executed her, but before her death she refused to give up any names of her comrades.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on September 03, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and people standing.

node.text:
On this day, 3 September 1934, 65,000 textile workers in North Carolina joined the strike of workers in Alabama against pay cuts. The strikers used their cars to drive to working mills and spread the strike.
Learn more about this mass strike in this book: https://shop.workingclasshistory.com/products/strike-jeremy-brecher
To access this hyperlink click the product link in the image or click our link in bio, swipe left then click this photo
